Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Cassandra L. Fraser is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Chemistry Division to conduct research on difluoroboron beta-diketonates that show reversible mechanochromic luminescence. These unusual pigments change emission color when scratched, crushed or smeared, and can self erase with time. Difluoroboron beta-diketonate dyes will be structurally modified and their solid state and solution properties thoroughly characterized to gain better mechanistic insight into the factors influencing initial and post shear emission properties, and thermal and self-healing kinetics.

These studies will provide insight into molecular and environmental factors affecting mechanochromic luminescence and suggest ways to more effectively control properties for imaging, sensing and detection applications such as opto-mechanosensors, security inks, tamper detection, intelligence and forensic uses, unprecedented self-erasing/rewritable responsive pigments for art, design, consumer products, and more. The proposed research provides unique interdisciplinary research and training experiences for graduate, undergraduate and high school students crossing chemistry, materials science, and physics. Creative arts and architecture collaborations and related university-wide interdisciplinary programs provide opportunities to explore design across the length scales and to share the excitement of science with broader audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mechanochromic luminescent (ML) materials change fluorescence color in response to mechanical stimuli. In 2010, our lab reported that a simple boron dye based on the sunscreen ingredient, avobenzone (AVB) displayed unusual reversible ML. That is, when thin films of BF2AVB are excited with UV light, they emit blue-green light, which, when scratched or smeared, turned yellow. Surprising, the smeared regions reverted back to their original blue-green color over minutes’ time, or in seconds, with heating. Then the dye coated surface can be marked and erased again many times. This unexpected but important finding was a first for boron compounds of this type, and at the time, was a very rare self-erasing system for any ML material. Our seminal paper has already been cited 321 times by investigators around the world. We filed a patent which has issued and call these renewable pigments Scratch the Surface InksTM to refer to their force responsive properties and limitless potential. Proposed uses for ML materials include mechanical sensors, security inks, concealed fugitive messages for intelligence contexts, dyes for art, design and practical uses, and many other imaging, sensing and detection schemes.

     This NSF project followed up on these surprising findings by exploring structure-property relationships in solid-state difluoroboron β-diketonate (BF2bdk) dyes.  That is, we adjusted features of the molecular structure, specifically, the β-diketonate ligand and various groups bound to its arene rings, to see how it would affect optical properties, namely brightness, original and smeared emission colors, and recovery times. We investigated dyes with different aromatic groups like benzene, naphthalene and thiophene, with halides such as F, Cl, Br or I, and greasy alkyl chains of different lengths. We also explored dyes with strapped and bulky groups that can affect the molecular structure and its ability to rotate, which in turn affects light emission. All of these parameters influence the optical properties of the dyes. Furthermore, we discovered that ML properties are even present without the BF2 group. Many β-diketones alone display ML that is even more rapidly recovering often times.  Because these boron-free dyes self-erase so quickly, that poses challenges for measurement and characterization. We developed an affordable laptop camera imaging system that allows for tracking of emission changes and allowed us to see that recovery happens faster in thicker versus thinner films. Film thickness effects outweigh substrate differences (glass versus chemistry weighing paper) in many cases. 

     Outcomes from our work include a number of publications, a patent, and numerous presentations by the PI and students of all ranks at K-12 schools, colleges, universities, and national and international meetings. Publications from this project have been highlighted as hot articles. Numerous graduate students, undergraduates and postdoctoral fellows have participated and helped advance the project. Their names appear as coauthors on publications. Undergraduates are prestigious fellowship recipients, namely Beckman Scholars and UVA Harrison Award winners. Three undergraduates who have worked in our lab and contributed to this project are pursuing or plan to pursue graduate work in chemistry. We have also hosted an underrepresented minority student in the lab for summer research. The PI is strongly committed to diversity and inclusion, as evidenced by leadership and involvements at the departmental college, university and national level. The project is highly interdisciplinary, and affords excellent opportunities for training in organic, inorganic, materials, and physical chemistry through characterization and computational studies. Our collaborative network is extensive, crossing chemistry, engineering, and even non-science fields. The dynamic, visually compelling nature of these dyes is also a big draw for the creative arts, sparking collaborations, exhibitions and presentations in art, design, music, and poetry. These cultural offerings provided opportunities to share the thrill of scientific discovery and the amazing properties of these colorful, dynamic and interactive materials with broader audiences. Likewise, interactions with artists and designers sparks new ideas for science. The nickel rubbing is an image that hangs near the Deans Office at the University of Virginia. Aptly, it features Thomas Jefferson’s Monticello. Fraser was recently elected a fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in recognition of her scientific contributions, innovative interdisciplinary and socially relevant pedagogy, and commitment to advancing equity in the academy.
